title-group.article-title: Application of a near-field acoustic holography-based diagnosis technique in gearbox fault diagnosis

abstract.p: With the combination of the near-field acoustic holography (NAH) and pattern recognition technique, a NAH-based diagnosis technique is proposed and applied to diagnose gearbox faults by analyzing the sound field distribution information first. After visualizing the sound fields under different working conditions by NAH, the spatial gray level co-occurrence matrices based textural features can be obtained from the NAH images. Then, the support vector machine is employed to identify different working conditions and diagnose the faults. Two gearbox experiments with different gear faults and fault severity are studied in a semi-anechoic chamber to verify the NAH-based diagnosis technique. The experimental results demonstrate that the NAH-based diagnosis method is feasible and effective, and can be anticipated as a choice for gearbox fault diagnosis.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Gearboxes are the key parts of machinery, and their failures may lead to downtime loss or even some disastrous catastrophe. Three main types of methodology have generally been applied to gearbox fault diagnosis, namely vibration analysis, debris monitoring (Dempsey, 2000, 2003; Dempsey and Afjeh, 2002; Loutas et al., 2009) and acoustic signal analysis (Baydar and Ball, 2001, 2003). The vibration analysis was the most popularly employed and many vibration-based analysis techniques were researched, such as the time synchronous average (Combet and Gelman, 2007), spectrum (Baydar and Ball, 2000), cepstrum (Badaoui et al., 2001), time–frequency (Staszewski et al., 1997), amplitude and phase modulation techniques (Wang et al., 2001). Although the vibration analysis techniques were very mature, vibration analysis based on contact measurement were restrained in some special circumstances, such as the high temperature, the high humidity, the space limitation and the conditions in which the machine cannot stop. Therefore, fault diagnosis techniques based on periodic non-destructive inspection are expected. Acoustic signals can be obtained in a non-contact way without the need to halt the machine, and can be an important choice for the non-destructive detection. However, comparing vibration analysis, the acoustic signals analysis has received little attention. For traditional acoustic-based diagnosis (ABD) techniques, the acoustic signals were usually measured by a single microphone and processed in the same way as vibration (Baydar and Ball, 2001, 2003; Benko et al., 2005; Chen and Wang, 2005; Li et al., 2002; Lu and Wei, 1999; Shibata et al., 2000; Xu et al., 2000). In addition, the microphone’s position could significantly influence fault analysis (Baydar and Ball, 2003) which needed some prior knowledge. Hence, the traditional ABD techniques, using the acoustic information only at a few points of the sound field, could not utilize the whole sound field distribution information for fault diagnosis, which may contain more fault information.

In fact, a gearbox system is nonlinear: the vibration energy at some positions on the gearbox casing increases nonlinearly with fault severity and, consequently, the acoustic energy at some regions of the sound field. The acoustic responses caused by different gear faults may change somewhat in some parts of the sound field but not in the global field. Therefore, the sound field distribution information of the gearbox can be exploited and may be more effective than single-channel measurement. In this study, a near-field acoustic holography (NAH)-based diagnosis procedure is developed for diagnosing gearbox fault. By using the NAH algorithm to visualize the sound field radiated from the gearbox, the new diagnosis method extracts some spatial gray level co-occurrence matrices (SGLCMs)-based textural features from the NAH images. Then, a support vector machine (SVM) is employed to identify different gear faults. The feasibility and effectiveness of the new technique are researched and verified by gearbox experiment, and one new diagnosis idea for gearbox fault diagnosis or other rotating machinery is presented simultaneously.

sec.title: 2.1. Technique flow
sec.p:
A running machine radiates sound noise, which results in a sound field enclosing the machine. The failures of a machine can influence not only the vibration but also its sound field. Different working conditions result in different sound field distributions, on the basis of which the NAH-based diagnosis technique is proposed. The new ABD technique not only retains the advantages of non-contact measurement but also employs the sound field distributions for fault diagnosis. Its diagnosis procedure, as shown in Figure 1, is schematically as follows:
Acoustic signals under all kinds of working conditions are sampled by microphone arrays while the machine is running, and one sample database including comprehensive sound field information is set up.
The NAH algorithm is applied to visualize the sound field distributions on the plane very close to the machine.
After obtaining the NAH images, the fault diagnosis using information of sound field changes can be treated as image pattern recognition, in which the image features are extracted and used as classification characteristics.
One feature space is generated by the image features, in which the features of one NAH image can be uniquely determined.
By using the SVM-based pattern recognition technique in the feature space, the acoustic images of different working conditions are classified. The optimal SVM classifier fitting for the training data can be generated.
The acoustic image features obtained from unknown conditions can be directly identified by the optimal SVM classifier, so that the fault condition can be diagnosed.
Figure 1.
The schematic of the NAH-based diagnosis technique.

sec.title: 2.2. Theory of NAH
sec.p: NAH is one of the hot techniques of visualizing a sound field, since it can reconstruct the sound field on any observing plane based on sound pressure measured on a two-dimensional holographic surface. The two-dimensional fast Fourier transform (2D-FFT) is employed to the Helmholtz’s equation, and the fast transform between spatial domain and wave number domain is achieved. Therefore, some sound field variables on the source plane, such as sound pressure, particle velocity, and sound intensity, can be reconstructed by the sound pressure on the holographic measurement plane.

In this study, the FFT-based NAH is employed to obtain the two-dimensional spatial distribution of sound pressure radiated from the gearbox. Figure 2 is the sketch map of sound field propagation. The holographic measurement plane Sh is at z = zh, the reconstruction plane Sc is at z = zc and the source plane Ss is at z = zs. The sound pressure on the reconstruction plane Sc is assumed as Φ(x, y, zc, f), the sound pressure on Sh is Φ(x, y, zh, f) and the Green’s function under the Dirichlet conditions is GD(x, y, zh-zc, f), so the generalized reconstruction equation is written as follows (Maynard et al., 1985): (1)Φ(x,y,zc,f)=F-1[Φ~(kx,ky,zk,f) ×G~D(kx,ky,zk-zc,f)]Φ~(kx,ky,zk,f)=F[Φ(kx,ky,zk,f)]Φ~(kx,ky,zc,f)=F[Φ(kx,ky,zc,f)]G~D(kx,ky,zh-zc,f)=F[GD(x,y,zh-zc,f)] where F represents the 2D-FFT, the superscript −1 denotes the inverse transform, kx, ky are the spatial wave numbers in the x and y directions, respectively. The two-dimensional spatial Fourier transform of G~D satisfying the homogeneous Dirichlet boundary conditions can be found explicitly: (2)G~D(kx,ky,zh-zc,f) =g{expg[j(zh-zc)k2-kx2-ky2g],kx2+ky2≤k2expg[-(zh-zc)kx2+ky2-k2g],kx2+ky2>k2g. When kx2+ky2≤k2, the expression of G~D represents the surface waves in the zc plane simply couple to ordinary propagating plane waves in the three-dimensional region zh > zc. When kx2+ky2>k2, surface waves with kx2+ky2>k2 must be matched with evanescent waves which has imaginary zh components in their wave vector, and which exponentially decays in the zh direction as exp[(zh-zc)kx2+ky2-k2]. Figure 2.
The sketch map of sound field propagation.

sec.title: 2.3. Feature extraction
sec.p: Before calculating SGLCM, the reconstruction sound pressure level matrices P(x,y) must be normalized to different gray level matrices (gray images) f(x,y) by using the quantized gray level L: (4)f(x,y)=int[P(x,y)-PminPmax-Pmin(L-1)]+1 where int is the round operator, Pmax and Pmin are the maximum and minimum values of P(x,y), respectively. The quantized gray level L can affect the gray image’s textural details, but not the larger the better. Therefore, five gray levels are selected in this study, which are 8, 16, 32, 64 and 128.

After obtaining the gray images with gray level L, the inter-sample spacing d is set as 1 and the angles θ are quantized to 45° intervals in this study, which are 0°, 45°, 90° and 135°. Based on each gray level L and angle θ, the SGLCM is calculated. Then, the corresponding 12 statistical features can be calculated, which are angular second moment, contrast, correlation, entropy, sum of squares, inverse difference moment, sum average, sum variance, sum entropy, difference average, difference variance, and difference entropy (Haralick et al., 1973). By comparing the diagnosis results, the best SGLCM with optimal gray level L and angle θ is obtained.

sec.title: 2.4. Support vector machine
sec.p: Fault diagnosis is essentially a kind of pattern recognition, and some pattern recognition techniques such as artificial neural networks (ANNs) and SVM have been employed to fault diagnosis (Jack and Nandi, 2002; Samanta, 2004). SVM is a new approach in machine condition classification, and it has gained acceptance in machine learning, computer vision and pattern recognition communities for its high accuracy and good generalization capability (Burges, 1998). It was based on the structural risk minimization principle from machine learning theory, in which the classification function was obtained by minimizing the mean square error (MSE) over the database (Cortes and Vapnik, 1995). During the training and testing procedure of SVM, the data file is always constituted by class labels yi and feature vectors xi from m-dimensional feature space xi ∈ Rm (i = 1, 2,…, n). SVM is originally designed for binary classification, so the class labels yi usually have two options, namely yi ∈ {−1, +1}. Here n denotes the number of training samples. With the application of some statistical theories and optimization methodologies, the establishment of a linear SVM problem is transformed into solving a quadratic convex programming problem (Chang and Lin, 2001): (5)min12‖wg‖2+C∑i=1nζisubjecttoyi[(w·xi)+b]≥1-ζig.ζi≥0,i=1,2,…,ng.

The hyperplane is defined by w · x + b = 0, where (w, b) are the parameters of the hyperplane, ζi is the so-called slack variable introduced to account for the non-separability of data, and the constant C represents a regularization parameter which allows us to control the penalty assigned to errors. After using Lagrange multipliers to satisfy Kuhn–Tucker conditions, the optimal hyperplane decision function can be found as follows: (6)f(x)=sgn{∑αiyi(xi·x)+b}

sec.title: 3. Gearbox fault diagnosis based on NAH
3.1. Experimental apparatus
sec.p:
The gearbox experiment is carried out in a semi-anechoic chamber, in which the acoustic signals radiated from the gearbox can be collected. The experimental test system, as shown in Figure 3, consists of a gearbox, an alternating motor, 5 reference microphones and a microphone array consisting of 17 microphones. The gearbox and the motor, joined together with a flexible coupling, are fixed firmly on the test rig. There is no loading device coupling with the output shaft, so the load is only from the internal friction of the gearbox. In the idling condition, weak fault signals may be covered easily, and only some severe faults can be diagnosed. Therefore, the gearbox experiment distinguishing some severe gear faults by the NAH-based diagnosis technique is designed. Figure 3.
Test system of the gearbox experiment.

The gearbox is a two-stage industrial helical reduction gearbox JZQ250, as shown in Figure 4. When the electrical motor runs at its rated speed 1500 rpm, the working frequencies of three shafts (f1, f2, f3) and two meshing pairs (f12, f34) are shown in Table 1. Figure 4.
Sketch of the gearbox JZQ250.

Frequency (Hz) 25 875 13.7 246 3.0

According to the NAH theory, the horizontal plane tangent to the top of gearbox is chosen as the reconstruction plane Sc, on which the acoustic distribution changes are used for fault diagnosis. The scanning measurement is employed (Wan and Jiang, 2006) to sample acoustic signals, as depicted in Figure 3. Five reference microphones are arranged near the gearbox to reserve the phase information, and the linear array moves step by step on the hologram plane Sh which is apart from the reconstruction plane Sc = 0.05 m. The distance between any two adjacent microphones of the linear array is 0.05 m, and the microphone array samples the acoustic signals at 23 scanning steps with 0.05 m scanning interval, so that the hologram is a horizontal plane with the size 1.1 m × 0.8 m paralleling to Sc.

The acoustic signals are measured and recorded by using a Müller BBM PAK 32. At each step the acoustic signals are sampled by the microphone array and references synchronously. The sampling rate is 4096 Hz, and the sampling length is 12 seconds. One sample file includes the acoustic signals sampled at all 23 steps, and 30 samples are collected in each kind of working condition.

sec.title: 3.2. Fault simulation
sec.p: In this study, the gear faults, such as pitting and partial tooth breakage, are artificially made to simulate different working conditions. In order to fully verify the feasibility of the new ABD technique and its effectiveness in gearbox fault diagnosis, two gearbox experiments with different failure complexities are implemented, which are the failures on a single gear and the failures on two gears.

In the experiment of a single gear with faults, a severe pitting fault is made on one tooth of gear Z3, as shown in Figure 5, so two conditions are simulated in the experiment: normal and pitting fault. By employing the NAH-based diagnosis technique to solve the problem, the diagnosis technique’s feasibility is verified, and a new feature frequency selection strategy is discovered. To further verify the technique’s feasibility and research the new feature frequency selection strategy, the experiment of two gears with faults is implemented, in which the pitting and partial tooth breakage faults are made on gear Z3 and gear Z1 sequentially, as shown in Figures 5–8. The two conditions of single gear with faults are reused in the experiment of two gears with faults, which can be seen as the special working conditions of the latter. Therefore, five working conditions are simulated, as shown in Table 2. Figure 5.

To keep the comparability of the acoustic signals under different working conditions, some operating procedures must be considered. First, the cover of the gearbox and the gaskets are pre-processed, so that the gearbox can be easily disassembled and reassembled and thus the installation errors can be reduced as much as possible. Second, the shafts, the bearings and the gears are firmly fixed in the gearbox, and the gear faults are directly machined on the gears by a hand drill, by which the offset influence of gearbox parts can be removed and the gear meshing conditions under different conditions can be consistent. Lastly, after making the gear faults, the gearbox cover must be assembled carefully, during which the mounting bolts must be installed sequentially. For each mounting bolt, the torque-indicating wrench is used by which the tightening torque remains the same as the first used in the test, and during the measuring, the mounting bolts are tightened for every 3–5 samples.

sec.title: 3.3. Failures on a single gear
sec.p:
In the experiment of a single gear with faults, a pitting fault is artificially made on only one gear tooth of gear Z3. Based on the traditional spectrum analysis of a gear fault, the most important components in gear vibration spectrum are the meshing frequency and its harmonics, together with sidebands due to modulation phenomena. In this study the fundamental meshing frequency f34 (246 Hz) and some of its side frequencies (218, 232, 260 and 274 Hz) are chosen as the feature frequencies. The NAH-based diagnosis technique employs the array measurement and NAH algorithm to reconstruct the acoustic images on the plane very close to the cover of the gearbox at all feature frequencies first; some images of sound pressure distribution are shown in Figures 9–13. Then, the acoustic images’ SGLCM-based features are applied to fault diagnosis. Five acoustic images of the five feature frequencies are obtained from one sample data, and 12 features can be extracted from each acoustic image. The feature vector of one sample data will include 12 × 5 feature parameters. Five gray levels are employed in this study, and for each gray level L there are four SGLCMs in the four directions, so there are 5 × 4 = 20 combinations and also 20 recognition results. In Figures 10 and 11 the sound pressure distributions have obvious changes, but in Figures 12 and 13 the positions of main sound sources change regularly with the working conditions. In Figure 9, both the sources’ positions and the sound pressure distributions can be observed clearly. Therefore, the NAH images at the meshing frequency are considered to include much fault information and can be used for fault diagnosis solely. To verify the idea, only the NAH images of meshing frequency are applied to diagnose the conditions and the recognition results are shown in Table 4. Table 4.

The good diagnosis results demonstrate that the NAH-based diagnosis technique is feasible and effective. For some reason, the 100% recognition ratio emerges in the experiment. First, the ideal experimental environment and the strict experimental procedure reduce some random disturbances and installation errors, by which the signals with high signal-to-noise ratios (SNRs) are obtained. Second, the severe gear faults are machined and can be easily identified. Finally, the SVM-based statistical diagnosis method can remove some random fluctuations in the gearbox.

On the basis of the images of sound pressure distribution of different conditions and diagnosis results in the single fault experiment, it is effective to use only acoustic image features of meshing frequency for fault diagnosis. The fault information at meshing frequency can be fully utilized by the NAH-based diagnosis technique. Only less recognition features are employed, and some uncertain problems at side frequencies can also be avoided. As a matter of fact, the side frequencies often emerge in normal conditions, which may be caused by some processing errors or installation errors of gears. The amplitudes’ differentia of side frequencies based on traditional spectrum analysis can hardly be used to diagnose fault even in some seriours fault conditions. Acoording to the spectrum analysis and modulation phenomena, the amplitude features of the meshing frequency and its harmonics were sensitive to many gear faults, but they usaully were utilized in company with their sidebands and seldom were applied to fault diagnosis by themselves (Dalpiaz et al., 2000). The NAH-based diagnosis technique can employ the sound field changes for fault diagnosis, which includes the acoustic information at a lot of spatial positions. The changes of sound field contain ample fault information, so only using fewer feature frequencies’ sound field change information can gain good diagnosis results.

sec.title: 3.4. Failures on two gears
sec.p:
To further verify the argument and research the new diagnosis technique, an experiment of gearbox failures on two gears is implemented and tested by only using the NAH images’ features of meshing frequencies. There are five working conditions in the experiment of two gears with faults, the pitting and partial tooth breakage faults are artificially made on gear Z1 and gear Z3, respectively. According to above-mentioned idea, only the two meshing frequencies (f12 and f34) responding to the two gears are chosen as the feature frequencies. All sample data from each kind of working condition is used to reconstruct sound field on the plane very close to cover of gearbox at the two feature frequencies, some acoustic images are shown in Figures 14–18, from which regular changes can be found. In part (a) of Figures 14–18 the acoustic images reconstructed at the gear Z3’s meshing frequency 246 Hz, the main sound source moves regularly with the working conditions. In condition 2, the pitting fault of gear Z3 makes the main sound source of acoustic image relative to its original position in normal condition 1 move left a little. Compared with condition 2, the main sound source moves up a little and the sound pressure distribution around the source becomes larger in condition 3 in which both gear Z1 and gear Z3 have pitting faults. In condition 4 the partial tooth breakage fault is machined on gear Z3, the sound source moves down a little and the pressure distribution also has some changes relative to condition 3. In condition 5, partial tooth breakage faults are made on both gear Z3 and gear Z1, the sound source moves up a little again and the pressure distribution becomes more extensively than in condition 4. In part (b) of Figures 14–18 at gear Z1’s meshing frequency 875 Hz, the positions of main sound sources have little change, but the sound pressure distributions change greatly.

Simultaneously, only employing the features at a few crucial feature frequencies for fault diagnosis by the NAH-based diagnosis technique is also verified.

sec.title: 3. Conclusions
sec.p: A NAH-based diagnosis technique is applied to gearbox fault diagnosis. The new ABD technique consists of array measurement, NAH algorithm, spectrum analysis, feature extraction and pattern recognition. After obtaining the NAH images in all kinds of working conditions, the SGLCM-based statistical texture features are extracted for fault diagnosis, by which the sound field distribution information enclosing the machinery are utilized first. A gearbox is experimentally studied to verify the feasibility and superiority of the NAH-based diagnosis method. The failures on single and two gears artificially simulated and studied by the new diagnosis technique. From the acoustic images in the two experiments, both the sound pressure distribution changes and the main sound sources can be recognized. The diagnosis results indicate that the new diagnosis procedure based on NAH images is available and feasible. The NAH-based diagnosis technique may be anticipated as an appealing tool in ABD techniques for gearbox fault diagnosis.
